intro: Houstonia caerulea f. albiflora, commonly known as the white-flowered bluebell, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale blue. The plant features slender, branching stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in woodland areas. The flowers bloom in early spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
